material.mattext: What does the term 'telecommunication' refer to?

What is the primary function of a telecommunication system?

Which of the following is a benefit of 3G mobile systems over 2G?
The introduction of 3G networks enabled which of the following services?
Which frequency band is typically used by WCDMA?
Which of the following technologies is NOT associated with 3G networks?
The core network component of a 3G system is referred to as:
In telecommunication, the term 'handover' refers to:
Transferring an ongoing call from one cell to another
Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for end-to-end communication?
A key feature of 3G technology is its support for:
Spreading the signal over a wide frequency band
The main purpose of the 'RNC' in a 3G network is to:
Control the radio resources and manage handovers
'HSPA' in the context of 3G stands for:
Which of the following is a characteristic of telecommunication systems?
The 'Node B' in a 3G network is analogous to which component in 2G networks?
Which technology does 3G use to allow multiple users to share the same frequency band?
A primary advantage of WCDMA is:
In 3G networks, what does the term 'soft handover' mean?
Simultaneous connection to multiple cells during handover
Which component of a telecommunication system is responsible for encoding and decoding information?
What is the purpose of the 'MSC' in mobile communication?
Handling local calls within a cell
The 'Handover' process in mobile communication is crucial for:
Maintaining call continuity when moving between cells
Which of the following layers of the OSI model deals with data presentation and encryption?
The transition from 2G to 3G networks primarily improved:
